term_description: A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
A name given to the study or project. Project title should be fewer than 30 words, such as a title of a grant proposal or a publication.
term_example: Study of single cells in the human body

term_description: A detailed description of the project which includes research goals and experimental approach. Project description should be fewer than 300 words, such as an abstract from a grant application or publication.
term_example: This project explores the intricate details of single cells in the human body, focusing on their structure, function, and behavior. By studying individual cells, it aims to uncover how they contribute to overall health, disease progression, and human biology. This research can provide deeper insights into cellular processes, paving the way for advancements in medical treatments and personalised medicine.

term_description: A citation for the study resource, following a standard format.
term_example: Doe J., et al. (2024). Single Cell Transcriptomic Analysis of Human Liver Cells. Journal of Cellular Biology.

term_description: The date when the study was created or registered.
The workflow or protocol followed during the study.
The sorting or visualisation technology used.
The first name of a Person.
The last name of a Person.
An organization that this person is affiliated with. For example, a school/university, a club, or a team.
A person or organization that supports (sponsors) something through some kind of financial contribution.
A Grant that directly or indirectly provide funding or sponsorship for this item.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for the  study if refering to
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the study.
The full scientific name of the species studied.
The full scientific name of the species studied.
The type of tissue sampled for the study.
A brief description of how the sample was preserved.
The date when the sample was collected with year, month and day specified in the format, YYYY-MM-DD.

The geographic latitude where the specimen or sample was taken in decimal degrees, between -90 and 90. Locations should be specified to a minimum of 3 decimal places and a maximum of 8 decimal places.
The longitude of the sample collection site, in decimal degrees.
The material or physical carrier of the resource.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier assigned to the sample in the study related to NCBI Taxonomy.
The full scientific name of the class in which the dwc:Taxon is classified.
The name, acronym, code, or initialism identifying the collection or data set from which the record was derived.
An identifier for the collection or dataset from which the record was derived.
The name of the continent in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
The standard code for the country in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than stateProvince (county, shire, department, etc.) in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
Part of the name of a cultivar, cultivar group or grex that follows the dwc:scientificName.
An identifier for the set of data. May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to a collection or institution.
The name identifying the data set from which the record was derived.
The date on which the subject was determined as representing the dwc:Taxon.
The current state of a specimen with respect to the collection identified in dwc:collectionCode or dwc:collectionID.
The name of the lowest or terminal infraspecific epithet of the dwc:scientificName, excluding any rank designation.
An identifier for the institution having custody of the object(s) or information referred to in the record.
The name of the island on or near which the dcterms:Location occurs.
The name of the island group in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
The full scientific name of the kingdom in which the dwc:Taxon is classified.
A language of the resource.
The specific description of the place.
Information about the source of this dcterms:Location information. Could be a publication (gazetteer), institution, or team of individuals.
An identifier for the set of dcterms:Location information. May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
Comments or notes about the dcterms:Location.
Comments or notes about the dwc:MaterialEntity instance.
term_example: found in association with charred remains

term_description: The greater depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in metres.

term_label: Maximum Distance Above Surface In Metres
term_description: The greater distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
The upper limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in metres.
The lesser depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in metres.

term_label: Minimum Distance Above Surface In Metres
term_description: The lesser distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
The lower limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in metres
An identifier for the dwc:Organism instance (as opposed to a particular digital record of the dwc:Organism). May be a globally unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
A number or enumeration value for the quantity of dwc:Organisms.
The type of quantification system used for the quantity of organisms.
Comments or notes about the dwc:Organism instance.
term_example: One of a litter of six

term_description: The full scientific name of the phylum or division in which the dwc:Taxon is classified.
A person, group, or organization responsible for recording the original dwc:Occurrence.
A list (concatenated and separated) of the globally unique identifier for the person, people, groups, or organizations responsible for recording the original dwc:Occurrence.
The reproductive condition of the biological individual(s) represented in the dwc:Occurrence.
The unit of measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling dwc:Event.
A numeric value for a measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling dwc:Event.
The amount of effort expended during a dwc:Event.
The methods or protocols used during a dwc:Event, denoted by an IRI.
The name of the first or species epithet of the dwc:scientificName.
The full scientific name of the subfamily in which the dwc:Taxon is classified.
The full scientific name of the subgenus in which the dwc:Taxon is classified. Values should include the genus to avoid homonym confusion.
An identifier for the taxonomic concept to which the record refers - not for the nomenclatural details of a dwc:Taxon.
Comments or notes about the taxon or name.
term_example: this name is a misspelling in common use

term_description: The status of the use of the dwc:scientificName as a label for a taxon. Requires taxonomic opinion to define the scope of a dwc:Taxon. Rules of priority then are used to define the taxonomic status of the nomenclature contained in that scope, combined with the experts opinion. It must be linked to a specific taxonomic reference that defines the concept.
The nature or genre of the resource.
The spatial coordinate system for the dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude or the dwc:verbatimCoordinates of the dcterms:Location.

The verbatim original spatial coordinates of the dcterms:Location. The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in dwc:verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in dwc:verbatimCoordinateSystem.
The original description of the depth below the local surface.
The original description of the elevation (altitude, usually above sea level) of the Location.
The verbatim original representation of the date and time information for a dwc:Event.
A string representing the taxonomic identification as it appeared in the original record.

The content of this term should include no embellishments, prefixes, headers or other additions made to the text. Abbreviations must not be expanded and supposed misspellings must not be corrected. Lines or breakpoints between blocks of text that could be verified by seeing the original labels or images of them may be used. Examples of material entities include preserved specimens, fossil specimens, and material samples. Best practice is to use UTF-8 for all characters. Best practice is to add comment ‚ÄúverbatimLabel derived from human transcription‚Äù in dwc:occurrenceRemarks.

The verbatim original latitude of the dcterms:Location. The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in dwc:verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in dwc:verbatimCoordinateSystem.
The original textual description of the place.
term_example: 25 km NNE Bariloche por R. Nac. 237

term_description: The verbatim original longitude of the dcterms:Location. The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in dwc:verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in dwc:verbatimCoordinateSystem.
The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which coordinates given in dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude, or dwc:verbatimCoordinates are based.
The taxonomic rank of the most specific name in the dwc:scientificName as it appears in the original record.
A common or vernacular name.
The vertical datum used as the reference upon which the values in the elevation terms are based.
An indication of whether a dwc:Organism was alive or dead at the time of collection or observation.
The name of the water body in which the dcterms:Location occurs.

An identifier for the dwc:MaterialSample (as opposed to a particular digital record of the dwc:MaterialSample). In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the dwc:materialSampleID globally unique.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
A unique alphanumeric code for the dissociation protocol in the study
A descriptive name of the protocol used for single-cell sequencing.
A free-text description of the process used to separate cells from tissues or cell aggregates.
term_example: Tissue was enzymatically dissociated using collagenase for 30 minutes.

term_description: Description of the specificity markers used to isolate cell populations, e.g. 'CD45+'. Please contact FAANG DCC to add more terms.
The kit used to isolate the cells.
Reference to literature sources that describe the protocol or methods used.
term_example: Doe et al. (2024), 'Single-cell RNA-seq: A comprehensive overview'

term_description: Reference link to protocols.io for additional details on the protocol.
Reference to the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) in workflow hub.
The method used to dissociate tissues into single cells.
Metrics used to assess the quality of single cells before sequencing.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier assigned to the cell suspension for the sample in the study.
A unique alphanumeric code for the dissociation protocol in the study
A unique alphanumeric code for the cell suspension for the sample
The type of suspension used to keep cells in solution during processing.
An number representing the number of cells in the sequencing library.
The percentage of living cells in a sample, indicating the health and quality of cells for RNA-sequencing analysis.
The method used to evaluate the viability of cells in the sample, often involving staining or flow cytometry techniques.
The size of the cell, typically measured in micrometres.
The volume of the cell suspension in microlitres.
The concentration of cells in the suspension.
The dilution factor of the cell suspension.
The volume of the cell suspension loaded into the single-cell RNA-sequencing system for analysis.

A solution used to dilute cell suspensions to a desired concentration, typically prior to loading cells into a device for single-cell RNA sequencing. It helps maintain cell viability and integrity during processing.
term_example: PBS (Phosphate-buffered saline) with 0.04% BSA (Bovine serum albumin)

term_description: A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the library preparation protocol used during the sequencing.
A unique alphanumeric code for the cell suspension for the library preparation.

Packaged kits (containing adapters, indexes, enzymes, buffers etc.), tailored for specific sequencing workflows, which allow the simplified preparation of sequencing-ready libraries for small genomes, amplicons, and plasmids
The version number of the library preparation kit used for sequencing.
The method used to amplify the Complementary DNA (cDNA).
The number of cycles used during the Complementary DNA (cDNA) amplification process.
The average length of RNA fragments in base pairs (BP) after library preparation, indicating the quality and suitability of the RNA for sequencing.
The library construction method (including version) that was used.
The specific fraction of biological macromolecule from which the sequencing library is derived.
The type of primer used for reverse transcription. This allows users to identify content of the cDNA library input for mRNA.
The end from which the molecule was sequenced.
The end bias of the library.
The Complementary DNA (cDNA) strand of the library from which the reads derived from - sense (first), antisense (second), both or none.
External RNA added to the sample as a control to assess technical variability and normalization in RNA-sequencing. State whether spike-in was used.
The specific type of external RNA used for spiking in, often indicating the source or nature of the control RNA.
The final concentration or dilution (for commercial sets) of the spike in mix.
Barcode sequence used on the i5 adapter during library preparation for identifying samples in multiplexed single-cell RNA-sequencing.
Barcode sequence used on the i7 adapter to distinguish samples in multiplexed sequencing runs.
Specifies if both i5 and i7 indices (dual) or only one index (single) was used for sample identification during sequencing.
The nucleotide sequence of the i5 index used in multiplexing during sequencing.
The specific nucleotide sequence of the i7 index used for a sample.
Identifier for the 96-well plate used in sample preparation.
The row identifier in a 96-well plate indicating the sample's position.
The column identifier in a 96-well plate indicating the sample's position.
The cell marker for the Fluorescence-Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) of cells.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the sequencing protocol.
The name of the sequencing platform used for the experiment.
This refers to the machine or platform used for sequencing, with variations in throughput, read lengths, error rates, and application suitability.
Specify whether to expect single, paired, or other configuration of reads for sequencing
The type of read that contains the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) barcode.
The offset in sequence of the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) identifying barcode.
The size of the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) identifying barcode.
The type of read that contains the UMI barcode.
The offset in sequence of the cell identifying barcode.
The offset in sequence of the cell identifying barcode.
The actual nucleotide sequence obtained from Complementary DNA (cDNA) during sequencing.
The starting position of the Complementary DNA (cDNA) read within the entire sequence, indicating where the read begins after any barcodes or technical sequences.
The size of the Complementary DNA (cDNA) read.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this file
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the library preparation protocol used during the sequencing.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the sequencing protocol.
The name or accession of the file that contains read 1.
The name or accession of the file that contains read 2.
The name or accession of the file that contains index 1.
The name or accession of the file that contains index 2.

Result of a hash function calculated on the content of both the read 1 file and the read 2 file to verify file integrity. Commonly used algorithms include MD5 and SHA-1. The checksums should be separated by a comma (,).

Result of a hash function calculated on the content of both the index 1 file and the index 2 file to verify file integrity. Commonly used algorithms include MD5 and SHA-1. The checksums should be separated by a comma (,).

A file containing the known cell barcodes in the
dataset.
A filename or file name is a name used to uniquely identify a data file related to the study.
A file type is a name given to a specific kind of file. Common file types are fastq, gtf, fasta, bam, etc.
The name or accession of the file which quantifies the level of gene, transcript, or protein expression in a given biological sample or condition.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
The name of the file that was used to generate the analysis derived data.
Post analysis cell type or identity declaration based on expression profile or known gene function identified by the performer.

Performer defined measure of whether the read output
from the cell was included in the sequencing analysis. For example, cells might be excluded if a threshold percentage of reads did not map to the genome or if pre-sequencing quality measures were not passed.
Any other cell level measurement or annotation as result of the analysis.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
Indicate version and include stable link to genome data (or attach genome fasta file).

Indicate version and include stable link. Also indicate if any modification to the original annotation has been applied (e.g. 3' UTR extension) and include modified annotation file employed in the analysis.
Indicate which features were filtered (i.e. protein coding, pseudo-genes, TCRs, etc.)
term_example: Filtered to include only protein-coding genes

term_description: Quantification using whole gene intervals or exons.
seqspec format
Reads/UMI
Statistics of the Reads or Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI).
Depending on number of cells recovered (not targeted) and technology
Show Unique Molecular Identifiers (UMIs) per barcode distribution and threshold applied
Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) threshold used to discriminate cells from non-cells. Description of algorithm (if any) and parameters used to determine cells or non-cells.
Cells/nuclei discarded based on % mitochondrial reads, % rRNA reads, etc.
Report % UMIs in background cell barcodes, and algorithm (if any) used to remove ambient RNA
term_example: Ambient RNA removed if >5% UMIs in background barcodes

term_description: Depending on number of cells recovered (not targeted) and technology
If carried out, show SNP partitioning quality (e.g. SNP UMAP embedding or covariance matrix), algorithm used
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
If compared/integrated with existing datasets
If compared/integrated with existing datasets
If compared/integrated with existing datasets
If any newly developed code/software has been used in the processing and downstream analysis of the dataset.
term_example: Source code is hosted on GitHub and includes custom algorithms for UMI count normalization. The repository can be found at: https://github.com/user/umi-normalization.

term_description: Gene x cell matrix with UMI counts for each gene in each cell.
term_example: The UMI count matrix is stored in a CSV file with gene IDs as rows (e.g., ENSG00000139618) and cell barcodes as columns (e.g., Cell_001, Cell_002). The matrix file is available at: https://example.com/umi_count_matrix.csv.

term_description: Gene or transcript names should be listed as Ensembl (or other standardized ID), with gene short names in metadata.
term_example: The UMI count matrix includes genes identified by their Ensembl IDs, such as 'ENSG00000139618' for the BRCA1 gene. See the full list of Ensembl IDs in the metadata file.

term_description: Any functional annotation generated/used (gene names, GOs, structural domains, etc.).
term_example: Functional gene annotations, including Gene Ontology (GO) terms, are provided in the metadata. For example, the gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) is annotated with the GO term 'GO:0003674' (DNA binding).

term_description: FASTA file with (or stable link to) the predicted proteins associated to genes in the UMI count matrix and matching IDs.
term_example: The protein sequences for genes are provided in a FASTA file available at: https://example.com/protein_models.fasta, where each protein sequence is linked to the corresponding gene ID.

term_description: Table mapping cell IDs to cluster/cell type/broad cell type annotations.
term_example: Cell metadata includes information such as cell type annotations ('Tumor', 'Normal') and experimental conditions ('Control', 'Treatment'). This data is available in a table at: https://example.com/cell_metadata.csv.

term_description: Expression tables that show normalised gene expression at the cluster or cell-type level.
term_example: Normalised gene expression data at the cluster level is provided in a tab-delimited text file. For example, gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) has expression values for clusters: Cluster_1: 1200, Cluster_2: 900. The full expression table is available at: https://example.com/cluster_level_expression.csv.

term_description: Necessary to re-use and interpret the data. E.g. barcode information in complex, serial multiplexing protocols (clicktags).
term_example: Barcode information used in multiplexing protocols is provided in a separate file, which can be accessed at: https://example.com/barcode_data.csv.

Variable aspects of an experiment design that can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI)

The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant
The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees, limited to 8 decimal points, and in WGS84 system

Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). Reference: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.
Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling.
Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier assigned to the sample in the study related to NCBI Taxonomy.

The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
The vertical distance below local surface. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples

Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit

term_label: Amount or Size of Sample Collected
term_description: The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected
Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating libraries
List of database(s) used for ORF annotation, along with version number and reference to website or publication
Temperature of the sample at the time of sampling in degree celsius
Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material

Heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds in metres (m). It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earth's surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air

A unique identifier assigned to a material sample used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field.

The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly)
To what is the entity pathogenic
The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa.
The device used to collect an environmental sample.
Description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associated with.
Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report
The range and diversity of host species that an organism is capable of infecting, defined by NCBI taxonomy identifier
The phylogenetic marker(s) used to assign an organism name to the SAG or MAG
Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123

List of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from the DO (Human Disease Ontology) at https://www.disease-ontology.org, non-human host diseases are free text
The method employed for collecting the sample
NCBI taxon id of the sample. Maybe be a single taxon or mixed taxa sample. Use 'synthetic metagenome for mock community/positive controls, or 'blank sample' for negative controls
Method used for taxonomic classification, along with reference database used, classification rank, and thresholds used to classify new genomes

term_description: Gene or transcript names should be listed as Ensembl (or other standardized ID), with gene short names in metadata.
term_example: The UMI count matrix includes genes identified by their Ensembl IDs, such as 'ENSG00000139618' for the BRCA1 gene. See the full list of Ensembl IDs in the metadata file.

term_description: Any functional annotation generated/used (gene names, GOs, structural domains, etc.).
term_example: Functional gene annotations, including Gene Ontology (GO) terms, are provided in the metadata. For example, the gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) is annotated with the GO term 'GO:0003674' (DNA binding).

term_description: FASTA file with (or stable link to) the predicted proteins associated to genes in the UMI count matrix and matching IDs.
term_example: The protein sequences for genes are provided in a FASTA file available at: https://example.com/protein_models.fasta, where each protein sequence is linked to the corresponding gene ID.

term_description: Table mapping cell IDs to cluster/cell type/broad cell type annotations.
term_example: Cell metadata includes information such as cell type annotations ('Tumor', 'Normal') and experimental conditions ('Control', 'Treatment'). This data is available in a table at: https://example.com/cell_metadata.csv.

term_description: Expression tables that show normalised gene expression at the cluster or cell-type level.
term_example: Normalised gene expression data at the cluster level is provided in a tab-delimited text file. For example, gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) has expression values for clusters: Cluster_1: 1200, Cluster_2: 900. The full expression table is available at: https://example.com/cluster_level_expression.csv.

term_description: A unique alphanumeric identifier for this study
A name given to the study or project. Project title should be fewer than 30 words, such as a title of a grant proposal or a publication.
term_example: Study of single cells in the human body

term_description: A detailed description of the project which includes research goals and experimental approach. Project description should be fewer than 300 words, such as an abstract from a grant application or publication.
term_example: This project explores the intricate details of single cells in the human body, focusing on their structure, function, and behavior. By studying individual cells, it aims to uncover how they contribute to overall health, disease progression, and human biology. This research can provide deeper insights into cellular processes, paving the way for advancements in medical treatments and personalised medicine.

term_description: Gene or transcript names should be listed as Ensembl (or other standardized ID), with gene short names in metadata.

term_description: Any functional annotation generated/used (gene names, GOs, structural domains, etc.).
term_example: Functional gene annotations, including Gene Ontology (GO) terms, are provided in the metadata. For example, the gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) is annotated with the GO term 'GO:0003674' (DNA binding).

term_description: FASTA file with (or stable link to) the predicted proteins associated to genes in the UMI count matrix and matching IDs.
term_example: The protein sequences for genes are provided in a FASTA file available at: https://example.com/protein_models.fasta, where each protein sequence is linked to the corresponding gene ID.

term_description: Table mapping cell IDs to cluster/cell type/broad cell type annotations.
term_example: Cell metadata includes information such as cell type annotations ('Tumor', 'Normal') and experimental conditions ('Control', 'Treatment'). This data is available in a table at: https://example.com/cell_metadata.csv.

term_description: Expression tables that show normalised gene expression at the cluster or cell-type level.
term_example: Normalised gene expression data at the cluster level is provided in a tab-delimited text file. For example, gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) has expression values for clusters: Cluster_1: 1200, Cluster_2: 900. The full expression table is available at: https://example.com/cluster_level_expression.csv.

term_description: Necessary to re-use and interpret the data. E.g. barcode information in complex, serial multiplexing protocols (clicktags).

term_example: This project explores the intricate details of single cells in the human body, focusing on their structure, function, and behavior. By studying individual cells, it aims to uncover how they contribute to overall health, disease progression, and human biology. This research can provide deeper insights into cellular processes, paving the way for advancements in medical treatments and personalised medicine.

The version number of the library preparation kit used for sequencing.
The method used to amplify the Complementary DNA (cDNA).
The number of cycles used during the Complementary DNA (cDNA) amplification process.
The average length of RNA fragments in base pairs (BP) after library preparation, indicating the quality and suitability of the RNA for sequencing.
The library construction method (including version) that was used.
The specific fraction of biological macromolecule from which the sequencing library is derived.
The type of primer used for reverse transcription. This allows users to identify content of the cDNA library input for mRNA.
The end from which the molecule was sequenced.
The end bias of the library.
The Complementary DNA (cDNA) strand of the library from which the reads derived from - sense (first), antisense (second), both or none.
External RNA added to the sample as a control to assess technical variability and normalization in RNA-sequencing. State whether spike-in was used.
The specific type of external RNA used for spiking in, often indicating the source or nature of the control RNA.
The final concentration or dilution (for commercial sets) of the spike in mix.

Barcode sequence used on the i7 adapter to distinguish samples in multiplexed sequencing runs.

The nucleotide sequence of the i5 index used in multiplexing during sequencing.
The specific nucleotide sequence of the i7 index used for a sample.

The row identifier in a 96-well plate indicating the sample's position.
The column identifier in a 96-well plate indicating the sample's position.
The cell marker for the Fluorescence-Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) of cells.

Specify whether to expect single, paired, or other configuration of reads for sequencing

The starting position of the Complementary DNA (cDNA) read within the entire sequence, indicating where the read begins after any barcodes or technical sequences.

Result of a hash function calculated on the content of both the read 1 file and the read 2 file to verify file integrity. Commonly used algorithms include MD5 and SHA-1. The checksums should be separated by a comma (,).

term_label: Maximum Distance Above Surface In Metres
term_description: The greater distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.

The lesser depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in metres.

It must be linked to a specific taxonomic reference that defines the concept.

A string representing the taxonomic identification as it appeared in the original record.

The content of this term should include no embellishments, prefixes, headers or other additions made to the text. Abbreviations must not be expanded and supposed misspellings must not be corrected. Lines or breakpoints between blocks of text that could be verified by seeing the original labels or images of them may be used. Examples of material entities include preserved specimens, fossil specimens, and material samples. Best practice is to use UTF-8 for all characters. Best practice is to add comment ‚ÄúverbatimLabel derived from human transcription‚Äù in dwc:occurrenceRemarks.

The original textual description of the place.

Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
The vertical distance below local surface. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples

Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit

Heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds in metres (m). It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earth's surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air

A unique identifier assigned to a material sample used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field.

The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly)
To what is the entity pathogenic
The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa.
The device used to collect an environmental sample.
Description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associated with.
Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report
The range and diversity of host species that an organism is capable of infecting, defined by NCBI taxonomy identifier
The phylogenetic marker(s) used to assign an organism name to the SAG or MAG
Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. List of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from the DO (Human Disease Ontology) at https://www.disease-ontology.org, non-human host diseases are free text
